case_name: State of Bihar v. Rambalak Singh

facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 200 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 200 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 24, 1965 of the Patna High Court in Criminal W.J.C. No. 126 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 24, 1965 of the Patna High Court in Criminal W.J.C. No. 126 of 1965.

facts.text: Patna High Court ordered that the detenu Rambalak Singh be released on bail of Rs. 500 with two sureties of Rs. 250 each to the satisfaction of the Registrar of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: ordering that the detenu Rambalak Singh be released on bail of Rs. 500 with two sureties of Rs. 250 each to the satisfaction of the Registrar of the High Court.

facts.text: Mr. Girish Nandan Sinha who appeared for the detenu gave an undertaking to the Court that during the pendency of the proceedings when the petitioner is on bail, the petitioner will not indulge in any prejudicial activity or commit any prejudicial act.

anchor.surface_text: The order further mentions that Mr. Girish Nandan Sinha who appeared for the detenu had given an undertaking to the Court that during the pendency of the proceedings when the petitioner is on bail, the petitioner will number indulge in any prejudicial activity or companymit any prejudicial act.

facts.text: Rambalak Singh is the detenu detained under Rule 30 of the Defence of India Rules.

anchor.surface_text: a detenu who has been detained under Rule 30 of the Defence of India Rules  hereinafter called the Rules

facts.text: Habeas corpus petition filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution on behalf of the detenu.

anchor.surface_text: whether while entertaining a habeas companypus petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution filed on behalf of a detenu who has been detained under Rule 30 of the Defence of India Rules

facts.text: Appellant is the State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Lal Narain Sinha, the Advocate-General of Bihar, has urged on behalf of the appellant, the State of Bihar

facts.text: Appellant not keen on obtaining reversal of the bail order but wants decision on point of law regarding jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Advocate-General stated at the outset that the appellant was number keen on obtaining the reversal of the order of bail which is under appeal he urged that the appellant wanted the point of law to be decided

facts.text: Court does not propose to deal with facts leading to the habeas corpus petition or propriety of the bail order.

anchor.surface_text: That is why we do number propose to deal with the facts leading to the habeas companypus petition on behalf of Rambalak Singh and will number companysider the propriety, or the reasonableness of the order under appeal.

facts.text: In Special Reference No. 1 of 1964, Legislative Assembly of Uttar Pradesh committed Keshav Singh to prison for its contempt.

anchor.surface_text: In that case, the Legislative Assembly of the State of Uttar Pradesh had companymitted Keshav Singh, who was number one of its members, to prison for its companytempt.

facts.text: Keshav Singh moved Allahabad High Court under Art. 226 and s.491 CrPC challenging committal and prayed for interim bail, which was granted.

anchor.surface_text: Keshav Singh had then moved the Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench, under Art. 226 of the Constitution and s. 491 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, challenging his companymittal as being in breach of his fundamental rights. He had also prayed for interim bail. The learned Judges who entertained his petition admitted him to bail

facts.text: Supreme Court in Special Reference No.1 of 1964 held that High Court had jurisdiction to grant interim bail to Keshav Singh.

anchor.surface_text: one of the points which arose for decision before this Court in the Special Reference was whether the order passed by the High Court admitting Keshav Singh to bail was without jurisdiction. ... this Court took the view that if Art. 226 companyfers jurisdiction ... the Court has numberjurisdiction to make an interim order in such proceedings?

facts.text: It is conceded that High Court can order release of detenu under R.30 if satisfied order passed mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: It is companyceded that even in regard to orders of detention passed under R. 30, it would be companypetent to the High Court to order release of the detenu if the High Court is satisfied that the impugned order has been passed mala fide.

facts.text: High Court can set aside detention order if invalid on face, e.g., passed by unauthorised authority.

anchor.surface_text: There is also -no doubt that the order of detention can be set aside if it appears to the High Court that on the face of it, it is Invalid, as for instance, when it appears to the High Court that the face of the order shows that it has been passed by an authority number empowered to pass it.

facts.text: Detention under R.30 is to safeguard defence of India, civil defence, public safety, etc.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that Patna High Court has jurisdiction to grant interim bail in such habeas corpus proceedings.

issues.text: whether the principle that conferment of jurisdiction under Art. 226 implies power to grant interim orders applies to habeas corpus proceedings challenging detention under Rule 30 of the Defence of India Rules

This argument, however, was rejected by this Court, because this Court took the view that if Art. 226 confers jurisdiction on the Court to deal with the validity of the order of commitment even though the commitment has been ordered by the House, how can it be said that the Court has no jurisdiction to make an interim order in such proceedings?

arguments.claim: High Court has jurisdiction to grant interim bail in R.30 habeas corpus under Art.226, though circumscribed by special considerations

anchor.surface_text: our conclusion is that in dealing with habeas corpus petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution where orders of detention passed under R. 30 of the Rules are challenged, the High Court has jurisdiction to grant bail

arguments.claim: Jurisdiction to grant interim bail limited: only on prima facie patent illegality; prefer expedited hearing over bail

holdings.text: in dealing with habeas corpus petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution where orders of detention passed under R. 30 of the Rules are challenged, the High Court has jurisdiction to grant bail pending final disposal

anchor.surface_text: our conclusion is that in dealing with habeas corpus petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution where orders of detention passed under R. 30 of the Rules are challenged, the High Court has jurisdiction to grant bail

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction under Art. 226 for main relief implies ancillary power for interim bail; general principle applies without exclusion by R.30

holdings.text: The principle that conferment of jurisdiction under Art. 226 implies power to grant interim orders applies to habeas corpus proceedings challenging detention under Rule 30

anchor.surface_text: The general principle on which the observations of this Court were based in the Special Reference would apply as much to the habeas corpus proceedings commenced on behalf of a detenu detained under R. 30 of the Rules as to any other habeas corpus proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of ratio from Special Reference No.1 of 1964 and State of Orissa v. Madan Gopal; no distinction warranted

holdings.text: The policy and object underlying the Defence of India Act and Rule 30 do not take away by necessary implication the High Court's jurisdiction to grant interim bail

anchor.surface_text: The policy underlying the enactment of the Defence of India Act and the Rules, and the object intended to be achieved by the detention which is authorised under R. 30, clearly indicate, that there are other valid considerations of paramount importance which distinguish the detention made under R. 30

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not impressed by distinction argument; if final jurisdiction exists, interim follows; no necessary implication of exclusion

holdings.text: An order granting bail to a detenu under Rule 30 pending habeas corpus petition is interim and auxiliary to the main relief, not final
holdings.reasoning_summary: Depends on authority for auxiliary relief, not nature of underlying order; interim if pending final disposal

holdings.text: High Court's jurisdiction to grant interim bail under Art. 226 to detenu under R.30 is narrow and circumscribed: only if prima facie patent illegality; prefer expedited hearing; issue return before prima facie on mala fides etc.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Preventive detention's object, non-justiciability of facts, need for State's return; balance liberty with public interest; distinguish existence from proper exercise

holdings.text: Rarity of High Courts granting bail in R.30 detention cases does not affect existence of jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: That is why we do not propose to deal with the facts leading to the habeas corpus petition on behalf of Rambalak Singh and will not consider the propriety, or the reasonableness of the order under appeal. holdings.reasoning_summary: Rarity irrelevant to pure question of jurisdiction

holdings.text: High Court can quash R.30 detention order if mala fide or invalid on face after full consideration

anchor.surface_text: Reference was also made to an earlier decision of this Court in the State of Orissa v. Madan Gopal Rungta and Others 1 , where it was ruled that an interim relief can be granted only in aid of, and as auxiliary to, the main relief which may be available to the party on final determination of his rights in a suit or proceeding. It is clear that this view proceeded on the well recognised principle that if jurisdiction is companyferred by a statute upon a Court, the companyferment of jurisdiction implies the companyferment of the power of doing all such acts, ,or employing such means, as are essentially necessary to its execution 1  1952 S.C.R. 28. edges.explanation: The holding regarding non-ouster of jurisdiction is grounded in the policy and object of the Defence of India Act
The prima facie illegality concept grounds the argument limiting jurisdiction to such cases.
The prima facie illegality standard grounds the holding that jurisdiction is narrow and limited to cases of prima facie patent illegality.
The prima facie illegality concept addresses the issue by providing the standard for jurisdictional limitations.
Narrow jurisdiction concept constrains the scope of High Court power as detailed in the holding to only patent illegality cases.
The concept grounds the holding by providing the basis for circumscribed jurisdiction in detention cases preferring expedited hearings.
The general concept of narrow jurisdiction supports the holding that High Court jurisdiction for interim bail is narrow, only for prima facie illegality.
The concept of narrow jurisdiction in detention cases, with limited review of subjective satisfaction, addresses the issue of limitations on High Court jurisdiction under Art. 226.

The limitations on mala fides as a groundnot a basis for hasty interim bail and requiring prima facie determination after State's returnsupport the holding's emphasis on narrow jurisdiction only for prima facie patent illegality with preference for expedited hearing.

The concept of preventive detention, which limits scope of judicial review and interim bail, is directly addressed by the issue concerning whether the underlying policy takes away jurisdiction for interim bail.

The holding that the policy does not take away jurisdiction for interim bail undercuts the general proposition in the preventive detention concept that it limits interim bail.

anchor.surface_text: That is why we do not propose to deal with the facts leading to the habeas corpus petition on behalf of Rambalak Singh and will not consider the propriety, or the reasonableness of the order under appeal. It is true, as the learned Advocate-General contends, that one rarely comes across a case where the High Court has purported to exercise its jurisdiction under Art. 226 and released a detenu on bail

It is conceded that even in regard to orders of detention passed under R. 30, it would be competent to the High Court to order release of the detenu if the High Court is satisfied that the impugned order has been passed mala fide. There is also no doubt that the order of detention can be set aside if it appears to the High Court that on the face of it, it is invalid
